text: hi everyone sothanyskruftano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new gojira
record
fortitude this is the latest lp from
beloved french metal outfit gojira their
seventh at this point with things still
moving full speed ahead
as they enter their third decade as a
band and with this new lp they still
seem to be sticking tightly to their
slow drift away
from their death metal roots that they
began in the 2010s
now with even more of an embrace of
groove metal
with some sludge metal thrown and of
course two and even all metal on this
new lp
i feel pretty confident in saying that
if you enjoy the band's 2016 record
magma you will most likely be
into this too because a lot of the sonic
elements of that record carry over onto
this one
but maybe slightly altered we still have
that chunky heavy guitar tone with the
occasional
digital pitch shifting technical but
very groovy drumming
some soaring reverb clean style vocals
too but
they seem more layered and reverb soaked
this time around
gojira on this record is sounding a bit
more ethereal but still heavy
and honestly part of me might prefer the
relative rawness
and nudity of magma a bit more still
there are loads of kick-ass tracks on
this record many of which were teased
before the release of this thing
i believe there were like five teasers
or singles to this record and it's just
11 tracks one of which is an intro to
another
effectively and between those tracks and
the deeper cuts i heard once i finished
the entire record
i loved a lot of what i was hearing
there's the intro track born for one
thing which is some
thunderous progressive sludge matched
with passages of pantera style riffing
its very mouth for war walk the band has
been working this combination of styles
for years now and they still have a
knack for it the way the riffs and drums
sync up at multiple points of the track
too
is great i mean the band just really has
an ability to showcase some very
technical but still visceral playing not
so
tight and robotic that it loses its soul
loses its excitement its thrill
though i will say on this track and a
few others too those
uh denser vocal harmonies we're hearing
on this record
do feel a little artificial like touched
up to the point where it's almost like
i'm hearing
synths more than i am vocals which i
don't necessarily think complements this
track aesthetically
there is amazonia another track i
enjoyed prior to release
but one that still perplexes me a little
bit first let me say it's actually a
very thoughtful track conceptually about
the
might but also destruction of the amazon
rainforest an area of the world that
many have referred to as our planet's
lungs the track
also features some of the best chugging
guitar riffs on the entire record some
b steel vocals a chilling bridge that's
topped with mystical guitar leads too
but what's odd the more i listen to it
is it's clear the band
wanted the instrumental to sound a
little
uh tribal maybe almost in like a soul
fly or a sepultura kind of way but the
attempt here that gojira makes to
pull this off is just painfully tacky
and shallow just like some very
bad woodwind playing and what sounds
like a jaw harp which to my knowledge
this instrument really like has no
connection to
this area of the world overall it's a
great song it's a great track but these
well-intentioned additions just come off
kind of
nutty the conscious bangers on this
record continue
on to another world some tight and
progressive
guitar arpeggios set a rigid foundation
for some of the most panoramic vocal
harmonies
on the entire record the lyrics here
further detail
our process as a species destroying this
planet and
anything worth saving within it and
yearning for another place to
be and exist as a result of that and the
biggest surprise on this cut is the
strangely groovy and psychedelic passage
that the whole song moves through around
the bridge
the very spacious outro is a nice touch
too at least on the intro the song hold
on
sees things moving in more of a
traditional classic rock or
progressive rock direction at least on
the guitar side
the whole first leg of the track is
anchored by these mesmerizing chant like
vocal passages
as well as a very driving and hypnotic
drum beat
while i think the singing is a bit funny
timbre wise i like that this portion of
the cut actually tries to
get in touch with that pre-historical
civilization
type vibe a bit more authentically
lyrically the song is all about a
tumultuous experience trying to fight
your way across a body of water to
find land and gojira does a great job of
making the sound so urgent
epic and life or death especially with
these
howling vocals and just massive chunky
guitar riffs
the more i listen to the track too i'm
sure you can interpret these lyrics as
being more of a metaphor
for life's general challenges and stress
too
now the middle of this record is where
things really start to slip
for me newfound there are aspects of
this track that
i like generally i think it sounds as
good as everything else here but
the riffs are really i think uh a little
basic
for gojira honestly these feel like
stale new metal leftovers meanwhile
there's some vocal effects on the track
that
remind me of like issues era corn seems
like a
weird reference point for the band i
don't know why i'm getting this vibe but
again it just feels like some uh bad
very basic
2000's era commercial metal stuff
meanwhile fortitude and the chant
are my least favorite tracks here at
least by a few miles
the chanted group sung vocal passage
that leads up to the chant
i don't think is particularly good or
well sung
but if that wasn't bad enough the lead
vocals on this track
too are the worst on the entire record
just some really sniveling cleans that
are nowhere near as good as the singing
on the rest of this lp i don't know why
there's such a gap in quality
from here and the rest of the record i
feel like i'm listening to some really
bad
musical theater production try to
incorporate some terrible metal number
in the middle of their play
the following track sphinx totally kicks
ass but for some reason i cannot get as
into into the storm as i would like the
drummer on this track is just
rocking that symbol bell which i don't
really mind the sound of the cymbal bell
when it's being used
sparingly or it's not mixed so high it's
one of the most prominent things
in the instrumental but it's so loud
here
and for some reason the rhythm that is
being played specifically on the symbol
bell
sounds like i'm listening to um a train
crossing signal
ding ding ding ding ding ding ding ding
ding
i was digging deeper into the track
hoping there was some kind of like
railroad reference going on here to kind
of justify
it but there's not granted it doesn't
take up the whole track but the portions
of the track it does are just completely
ruined for me
the trails is another underwhelming and
somewhat awkward moment on the lp i'm
noticing a pattern that whenever the
band backs off a bit and tries to do
something mellow
it just feels a bit off but at least the
closing track of the record ends things
off somewhat climactically and brings
back a theme mentioned earlier on the lp
giving into a grind
giving into conformity life itself being
a
a grind and a stress and i guess a
a challenge that is uh always ongoing
not necessarily one you benefit from
though gojira's portrayal here
uh feels more like a hellish trial
something you're sort of just
shoved into until you just give up and
give in
overall i will say i think this is a
pretty good record from the band
there were a couple tracks that were
just non-starters for me
a couple others that i think could have
used some retooling but
generally there are a lot of very well
written produced and performed songs
here i'm liking the
incredible lyrical focus as you usually
get with gojira but still
it's a consistent high point of the band
for them to go into their songs with
some thoughtful lyrics and ideas and
stories to tell
yeah sure it's not quite on the same
level as their classic progressive 2000s
era stuff
but certainly more highlights than duds
on this thing feeling a strong six to a
light seven
on this record tran position have you
given this record a listen did you love
it did you hate it what would you rate
it you're the best you're the best what
should i review next
